awd_titl_txt: Universal and Non-Universal Few-Body Physics in the Ultracold
awd_abstract_narration:
Few-body physics has played a prominent role in atomic, molecular and nuclear physics since the early days of quantum mechanics. A microscopic description of universal and non-universal aspects of ultracold s-wave interacting atomic few-body systems with up to six particles is planned. Specifically, a hyperspherical explicitly correlated Gaussian approach (HECG) applicable to four- and five-body systems with finite orbital angular momentum will be develoepd. Together with the "standard" explicitly correlated Gaussian approach, this approach will be applied to few-atom systems with various symmetries and  large s-wave scattering lengths. Moreover, the physics of few-body systems in periodic structures (a periodic box or an optical lattice) will be investigated. Lastly, microscopic finite-temperature approaches will be developed and applied.

The algorithm developments are expected to have implications for a variety of subdisciplines within physics and chemistry. The successful generalization of the HECG approach to states with finite angular momentum is expected to provide access to single- and multi-channel scattering observables. As such, the developed approach may find applications in nuclear and chemical physics, in addition to applications in atomic and molecular physics. The applications to ultracold few-body systems will significantly enhance our understanding of fundamental, yet highly correlated, few-body states, which govern much of the dynamics of ultracold quantum gases. Students will be actively involved in all aspects of the proposed research activities including the planning of the fundamental studies, the calculations and the interpretation and dissimination of the results. The research training of undergraduate and graduate students  in atomic theory with emphasis on analytical and numerical techniques prepares them for a wide variety of future pursuits. Students' classroom experiences will be improved by incorporating some of the latest advances.

por.por_cntn:
Few-body physics plays an important role in many areas of physics. The classical motion of three orbiting planets, governed by the gravitational force, is a textbook example that impressively illustrates the richness of few-body physics. While the two-body problem is readily solved analytically, the addition of the third planet makes the problem, in general, unsolvable by analytical means. The three-body problem is rich, displaying regular and chaotic motion. The quantum analog, namely three charged particles interacting through the Coulomb force, is equally rich and continues to capture researchers' attention. Over the past 20 years or so, significant progress has been made in the four- and higher-body sectors of quantum mechanical systems. The motivations for going beyond three particles are
manifold. Four-body Coulomb scattering problems, such as the system consisting of two electrons and two positrons, are of great interest to experimental efforts that are geared toward creating a positronium Bose-Einstein condensate. Scattering and bound state calculations for
nuclear four-body systems provide important benchmarks for modern nuclear potentials that, typically, contain two- and three-body terms but not four-body terms. Comparison with experimental data benchmark the predictability of the low-energy potentials derived within the chiral effective field theory framework and will, ultimately, help determine the four-body contribution to the interaction.

With the realization of ultracold atom systems, new classes of few-body systems have become available or are expected to become available in the near future experimentally. For example, ultracold few-fermion systems in effectively one-dimensional confinement have already been prepared with high fidelity. Experimental probes include radio frequency and tunneling spectroscopy. The research activities conducted under this NSF grant capitalized on the many experimental and theoretical advances in the field of cold atom physics, and investigated several classes of few-body systems
that are both of fundamental importance and of direct relevance to on-going or anticipated experiments. Research conducted resulted in a microscopic description of universal and non-universal aspects of s-wave interacting
atomic few-body systems with up to six particles. To this end, a new numerical approach that utilizes hyperspherical coordinates was developed.
Moreover, the physics of few-body systems in periodic structures was investigated. A new approach with applications in cold atom, nuclear and high-energy physics was developed. Lastly, microscopic finite-temperature approaches was developed and applied.

Several graduate students were trained as part of this project. The research training of graduate students in atomic theory with emphasis on analytical and numerical techniques prepares them for a wide variety of future pursuits.
Students' classroom experiences were improved by incorporating some of the latest advances.
